trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus topics (Java) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus topics (Java) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions in Azure. Code samples are written for Java applications.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions in Azure. Code samples are written for Java applications.

trans-unit.source: This guide describes how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: This guide describes how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in Java and use the <linkText>Azure SDK for Java</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in Java and use the <linkText>Azure SDK for Java</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include creating topics and subscriptions, creating subscription filters, sending messages to a topic, receiving messages from a subscription, and deleting topics and subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include creating topics and subscriptions, creating subscription filters, sending messages to a topic, receiving messages from a subscription, and deleting topics and subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have installed the <linkText>Azure SDK for Java</linkText><title></title> before building this sample.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have installed the <linkText>Azure SDK for Java</linkText><title></title> before building this sample.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Eclipse, you can install the <linkText>Azure Toolkit for Eclipse</linkText><title></title> that includes the Azure SDK for Java.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Eclipse, you can install the <linkText>Azure Toolkit for Eclipse</linkText><title></title> that includes the Azure SDK for Java.

trans-unit.source: You can then add the Microsoft Azure Libraries for Java to your project:
trans-unit.target: You can then add the Microsoft Azure Libraries for Java to your project:

trans-unit.source: Add the following import statements to the top of the Java file:
trans-unit.target: Add the following import statements to the top of the Java file:

trans-unit.source: Add the Azure Libraries for Java to your build path and include it in your project deployment assembly.
trans-unit.target: Add the Azure Libraries for Java to your build path and include it in your project deployment assembly.

trans-unit.source: Management operations for Service Bus topics can be performed via the ServiceBusContract class.
trans-unit.target: Management operations for Service Bus topics can be performed via the ServiceBusContract class.

trans-unit.source: A ServiceBusContract object is constructed with an appropriate configuration that encapsulates the SAS token with permissions to manage it, and the ServiceBusContract class is the sole point of communication with Azure.
trans-unit.target: A ServiceBusContract object is constructed with an appropriate configuration that encapsulates the SAS token with permissions to manage it, and the ServiceBusContract class is the sole point of communication with Azure.

trans-unit.source: The ServiceBusService class provides methods to create, enumerate, and delete topics.
trans-unit.target: The ServiceBusService class provides methods to create, enumerate, and delete topics.

trans-unit.source: The example below shows how a ServiceBusService object can be used to create a topic named "TestTopic", with a namespace named "HowToSample":
trans-unit.target: The example below shows how a ServiceBusService object can be used to create a topic named "TestTopic", with a namespace named "HowToSample":

trans-unit.source: There are methods on TopicInfo that enable properties of the topic to be tuned (for example: to set the default "time-to-live" value to be applied to messages sent to the topic).
trans-unit.target: There are methods on TopicInfo that enable properties of the topic to be tuned (for example: to set the default "time-to-live" value to be applied to messages sent to the topic).

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create a topic named "TestTopic" with a maximum size of 5GB:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create a topic named "TestTopic" with a maximum size of 5GB:

trans-unit.source: Note that you can use the listTopics method on ServiceBusContract objects to check if a topic with a specified name already exists within a service namespace.
trans-unit.target: Note that you can use the listTopics method on ServiceBusContract objects to check if a topic with a specified name already exists within a service namespace.

trans-unit.source: Topic subscriptions are also created with the ServiceBusService class.
trans-unit.target: Topic subscriptions are also created with the ServiceBusService class.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions are named and can have an optional filter that restricts the set of messages passed to the subscription's virtual queue.
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions are named and can have an optional filter that restricts the set of messages passed to the subscription's virtual queue.

trans-unit.source: The MatchAll filter is the default filter that is used if no filter is specified when a new subscription is created.
trans-unit.target: The MatchAll filter is the default filter that is used if no filter is specified when a new subscription is created.

trans-unit.source: When the MatchAll filter is used, all messages published to the topic are placed in the subscription's virtual queue.
trans-unit.target: When the MatchAll filter is used, all messages published to the topic are placed in the subscription's virtual queue.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a subscription named "AllMessages" and uses the default MatchAll filter.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a subscription named "AllMessages" and uses the default MatchAll filter.

trans-unit.source: You can also setup filters that allow you to scope which messages sent to a topic should show up within a specific topic subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can also setup filters that allow you to scope which messages sent to a topic should show up within a specific topic subscription.

trans-unit.source: The most flexible type of filter supported by subscriptions is the SqlFilter, which implements a subset of SQL92.
trans-unit.target: The most flexible type of filter supported by subscriptions is the SqlFilter, which implements a subset of SQL92.

trans-unit.source: SQL filters operate on the properties of the messages that are published to the topic.
trans-unit.target: SQL filters operate on the properties of the messages that are published to the topic.

trans-unit.source: For more details about the expressions that can be used with a SQL filter, review the SqlFilter.SqlExpression syntax.
trans-unit.target: For more details about the expressions that can be used with a SQL filter, review the SqlFilter.SqlExpression syntax.

trans-unit.source: The example below creates a subscription named "HighMessages" with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a custom MessageNumber property greater than 3:
trans-unit.target: The example below creates a subscription named "HighMessages" with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a custom MessageNumber property greater than 3:

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the following example creates a subscription named "LowMessages" with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a MessageNumber property less than or equal to 3:
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the following example creates a subscription named "LowMessages" with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a MessageNumber property less than or equal to 3:

trans-unit.source: When a message is now sent to the "TestTopic", it will always be delivered to receivers subscribed to the "AllMessages" topic subscription, and selectively delivered to receivers subscribed to the "HighMessages" and "LowMessages" topic subscriptions (depending upon the message content).
trans-unit.target: When a message is now sent to the "TestTopic", it will always be delivered to receivers subscribed to the "AllMessages" topic subscription, and selectively delivered to receivers subscribed to the "HighMessages" and "LowMessages" topic subscriptions (depending upon the message content).

trans-unit.source: To send a message to a Service Bus Topic, your application will obtain a ServiceBusContract object.
trans-unit.target: To send a message to a Service Bus Topic, your application will obtain a ServiceBusContract object.

trans-unit.source: The below code demonstrates how to send a message for the "TestTopic" topic we created above within our "HowToSample" service namespace:
trans-unit.target: The below code demonstrates how to send a message for the "TestTopic" topic we created above within our "HowToSample" service namespace:

trans-unit.source: Messages sent to Service Bus Topics are instances of the BrokeredMessage class.
trans-unit.target: Messages sent to Service Bus Topics are instances of the BrokeredMessage class.

trans-unit.source: BrokeredMessage objects have a set of standard methods (such as setLabel and TimeToLive), a dictionary that is used to hold custom application specific properties, and a body of arbitrary application data.
trans-unit.target: BrokeredMessage objects have a set of standard methods (such as setLabel and TimeToLive), a dictionary that is used to hold custom application specific properties, and a body of arbitrary application data.

trans-unit.source: An application can set the body of the message by passing any serializable object into the constructor of the BrokeredMessage, and the appropriate DataContractSerializer will then be used to serialize the object.
trans-unit.target: An application can set the body of the message by passing any serializable object into the constructor of the BrokeredMessage, and the appropriate DataContractSerializer will then be used to serialize the object.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, a java.io.InputStream can be provided.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, a java.io.InputStream can be provided.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to send five test messages to the "TestTopic" MessageSender we obtained in the code snippet above.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to send five test messages to the "TestTopic" MessageSender we obtained in the code snippet above.

trans-unit.source: Note how the MessageNumber property value of each message varies on the iteration of the loop (this will determine which subscriptions receive it):
trans-unit.target: Note how the MessageNumber property value of each message varies on the iteration of the loop (this will determine which subscriptions receive it):

trans-unit.source: Service Bus topics support a maximum message size of 256 MB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 MB).
trans-unit.target: Service Bus topics support a maximum message size of 256 MB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 MB).

trans-unit.source: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a topic but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a topic.
trans-unit.target: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a topic but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a topic.

trans-unit.source: This topic size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.
trans-unit.target: This topic size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.

trans-unit.source: The primary way to receive messages from a subscription is to use a ServiceBusContract object.
trans-unit.target: The primary way to receive messages from a subscription is to use a ServiceBusContract object.

trans-unit.source: Received messages can work in two different modes: ReceiveAndDelete and PeekLock.
trans-unit.target: Received messages can work in two different modes: ReceiveAndDelete and PeekLock.

trans-unit.source: When using the ReceiveAndDelete mode, receive is a single-shot operation - that is, when Service Bus receives a read request for a message, it marks the message as being consumed and returns it to the application.
trans-unit.target: When using the ReceiveAndDelete mode, receive is a single-shot operation - that is, when Service Bus receives a read request for a message, it marks the message as being consumed and returns it to the application.

trans-unit.source: ReceiveAndDelete mode is the simplest model and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.
trans-unit.target: ReceiveAndDelete mode is the simplest model and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.

trans-unit.source: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.
trans-unit.target: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.

trans-unit.source: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.
trans-unit.target: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.

trans-unit.source: In PeekLock mode, receive becomes a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.
trans-unit.target: In PeekLock mode, receive becomes a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.

trans-unit.source: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.
trans-unit.target: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.

trans-unit.source: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling Delete on the received message.
trans-unit.target: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling Delete on the received message.

trans-unit.source: When Service Bus sees the Delete call, it will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the topic.
trans-unit.target: When Service Bus sees the Delete call, it will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the topic.

trans-unit.source: The example below demonstrates how messages can be received and processed using PeekLock mode (not the default mode).
trans-unit.target: The example below demonstrates how messages can be received and processed using PeekLock mode (not the default mode).

trans-unit.source: The example below performs a loop and processes messages in the "HighMessages" subscription and then exits when there are no more messages (alternatively, it could be set to wait for new messages).
trans-unit.target: The example below performs a loop and processes messages in the "HighMessages" subscription and then exits when there are no more messages (alternatively, it could be set to wait for new messages).

trans-unit.source: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.

trans-unit.source: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlockMessage method on the received message (instead of the deleteMessage method).
trans-unit.target: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlockMessage method on the received message (instead of the deleteMessage method).

trans-unit.source: This will cause Service Bus to unlock the message within the topic and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.
trans-unit.target: This will cause Service Bus to unlock the message within the topic and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.

trans-unit.source: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the topic, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then Service Bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.
trans-unit.target: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the topic, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then Service Bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.

trans-unit.source: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the deleteMessage request is issued, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.
trans-unit.target: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the deleteMessage request is issued, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.

trans-unit.source: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.
trans-unit.target: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.

trans-unit.source: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.
trans-unit.target: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.

trans-unit.source: This is often achieved using the getMessageId method of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.
trans-unit.target: This is often achieved using the getMessageId method of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.

trans-unit.source: The primary way to delete topics and subscriptions is to use a ServiceBusContract object.
trans-unit.target: The primary way to delete topics and subscriptions is to use a ServiceBusContract object.

trans-unit.source: Deleting a topic will also delete any subscriptions that are registered with the topic.
trans-unit.target: Deleting a topic will also delete any subscriptions that are registered with the topic.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions can also be deleted independently.
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions can also be deleted independently.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of Service Bus queues, see the MSDN topic <linkText>Service Bus Queues, Topics, and Subscriptions</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of Service Bus queues, see the MSDN topic <linkText>Service Bus Queues, Topics, and Subscriptions</linkText><title></title> for more information.
